"My little homestead in the city, which I recently insured for ï¿¡2,000 would no doubt have shared the common fate, as the insurance companies will not make good that which is destroyed by the Queen's enemies. And although I have a farm of 50 acres close to the town, no doubt the crops and premises would have been destroyed. In fact, this has already partly been the case, and I am now suing the Government for damages done by a contingent of 1,500 natives that have recently encamped not many hundred yards from the place, who have done much damage all around."
Letter from a British citizen to his sister during the Anglo-Zulu War, South Africa, 1879

A historian researching nineteenth-century conflicts in South Africa would most likely find this letter a useful source for information about which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The diffusion of cultural practices throughout South Africa</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Economic boons present in British colonies</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Daily challenges of Afrikaners during the colonial period</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Unforeseen consequences of British imperialism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The letter describes the difficulties that one settler encountered upon arriving in South Africa. The British settled South Africa, among other colonies, with little regard for the population that already lived there. There is no evidence for the diffusion of the two cultures, so eliminate (A). The author discusses the economic difficulties he experiences, so there is no discussion of a boon; eliminate (B). You can also eliminate (C), as the author is British, not Afrikaner, and does not mention Afrikaners. Thus, the best answer is (D).

content:
"My little homestead in the city, which I recently insured for ï¿¡2,000 would no doubt have shared the common fate, as the insurance companies will not make good that which is destroyed by the Queen's enemies. And although I have a farm of 50 acres close to the town, no doubt the crops and premises would have been destroyed. In fact, this has already partly been the case, and I am now suing the Government for damages done by a contingent of 1,500 natives that have recently encamped not many hundred yards from the place, who have done much damage all around."
Letter from a British citizen to his sister during the Anglo-Zulu War, South Africa, 1879

The inclusion of the author's pending litigation with the British government serves to do which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Highlight the extent of the author's property losses</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Express his opposition to the ongoing war</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Belittle British officials</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Place blame on both his home country as well as the Zulus</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The author not only tells his sister of his conflict with the Zulu, but he also expresses frustration with the fact that the insurance company will not cover his loses. He is therefore going to sue the British government. The author seems caught in the middle and has conflicts with both parties. The amount of exact loss is not mentioned, so eliminate (A). He does not give an opinion on the war, so (B) is incorrect. While the author is critical of the British government, he does not specify any officials and merely says that he is suing the British government in general, so eliminate (C). Choice (D) is the best answer.

content:
Image courtesy of ChinesePosters.net.
"Brave the wind and the waves; everything has remarkable abilities." Chinese poster, 1958

Which economic philosopher most influenced the message of this poster?

answers.A: <label>A. John Stuart Mill</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Adam Smith</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Karl Marx</label>
answers.D: <label>D. David Ricardo</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

The poster, which is propaganda for the Great Leap Forward, represents Mao Zedong's vision for China. Since China became a communist nation under Mao, the obvious influence should be Karl Marx, (C).

content:
Image courtesy of ChinesePosters.net.
"Brave the wind and the waves; everything has remarkable abilities." Chinese poster, 1958

Which of the following is NOT a result of the Great Leap Forward's outcomes?

answers.A: <label>A. China strengthened its alliance with the Soviet Union.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Cultural Revolution was initiated.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Chinese adopted elements of capitalism.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Chinese changed their focus to military matters.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

The Great Leap Forward ultimately failed to industrialize China, due in no small part to diminished support from the Soviet Union, which was not pleased with the direction in which China was taking communism. The failure of the Great Leap Forward led to some radical changes for China, including the Cultural Revolution, (B); the adoption of some capitalist practices, (C); and the beefing up of its military, (D). Therefore, eliminate (B), (C), and (D), and choose (A).

content:
Image courtesy of ChinesePosters.net.
"Brave the wind and the waves; everything has remarkable abilities." Chinese poster, 1958

In what way was the Great Leap Forward different from the Soviet Union's Five Year Plan?

answers.A: <label>A. The Great Leap Forward focused only on industrial production, while the Five Year Plan also took on agricultural production.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Unlike the Soviet Union, China was unable to successfully industrialize during this period.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Mao utilized a process of collectivization in his plan, a technique eschewed by Stalin.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Historians attribute mass starvation to the Great Leap Forward, but do not see similar consequences to the Five Year Plan.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Both the Great Leap Forward and the Five Year Plan sought to propel industrial and agricultural output, but China was unable to industrialize in the way that the Soviet Union was able to. Eliminate (A). Choice (C) is also incorrect because collectivization, the government takeover of businesses, was the method that drove both plans. The Five Year Plan led to starvation, particularly for the farmers, as Stalin prioritized feeding government workers, so eliminate (D). Choice (B) is correct.

content:
Image courtesy of ChinesePosters.net.
"Brave the wind and the waves; everything has remarkable abilities." Chinese poster, 1958

The images on the poster best reflect which of the following ambitions of the People's Republic of China?

answers.A: <label>A. To cut off ties with the non-communist world</label>
answers.B: <label>B. To have all citizens contribute to China's industrialization</label>
answers.C: <label>C. To launch the Cultural Revolution</label>
answers.D: <label>D. To form a friendlier alliance with Taiwan</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

The poster shows citizens from all walks of life in China contributing to industry and agriculture, which is consistent with (B).

content: Which of the following is NOT a consequence of the Mediterranean and the Thessalio-Danubian branches establishing settlements?

answers.A: <label>A. The groups began to use animals for labor.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Settlers were able to manipulate metals.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Wars became more frequent.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Settlers had difficulty providing enough food.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

Use POE on this question. Choice (A) describes a technique used by settled groups who began to practice agriculture, a key element of Neolithic humans, so get rid of (A). The Neolithic Era was also known as the Bronze Age, as humans figured out how to combine metals; eliminate (B). Choice (C) is another true statement: The settling of groups led to the creation of land borders and, therefore, conflicts over those borders. Choice (D) is the answer.

content: The map would support which of the following conclusions?

answers.A: <label>A. The Mediterranean branch represents a more successful seafaring people than does the Thessalio-Danubian branch.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The people of the black and gray pottery staged invasions as far as Scandinavia.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Thessalio-Danubian branch had a significant impact on what would become the British Isles.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. By 5000 B.C.E., both the Mediterranean branch and the Thessalio-Danubian branch had settled into sedentary societies.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

The map shows much of the movement of the Mediterranean branch throughout the waters off of Greece, Italy, and Spain. The map indicates that the Thessalio-Danubian branch travels almost exclusively on land. This would qualify the Mediterranean branch as the more successful seafarers, so (A) is correct.

content:
"In Northern India the existence of separate States at this period is usually little more than a question of words. A zamindar who paid revenue to the Mogul was clearly in a position of dependence, and if he wished to establish a claim to sovereignty, the first step was to refuse, or omit to pay revenue. Such an omission might, however, arise from various other causes, and it is probable that in Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur there were numerous chiefs and tribes occupying what constitutional lawyers would regard as an anomalous position, sometimes paying the stipulated revenue, sometimes in open rebellion, and sometimes enjoying practical independence because the Mogul authorities found it inconvenient to undertake active measures of coercion."
W.H. Moreland, India at the Death of Akbar, 1920

Which of the following characteristics most accurately defines the "zamindar[s]" mentioned in the text?

answers.A: <label>A. Muslim landowners</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Buddhist peasants</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sikh nobility</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Hindu aristocrats</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The zamindars were nobles in India at the time the Islamic Mughal Empire was established. Since they were native to India, it can be reasonably concluded that they were Hindu, which is (D).

content:
"In Northern India the existence of separate States at this period is usually little more than a question of words. A zamindar who paid revenue to the Mogul was clearly in a position of dependence, and if he wished to establish a claim to sovereignty, the first step was to refuse, or omit to pay revenue. Such an omission might, however, arise from various other causes, and it is probable that in Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur there were numerous chiefs and tribes occupying what constitutional lawyers would regard as an anomalous position, sometimes paying the stipulated revenue, sometimes in open rebellion, and sometimes enjoying practical independence because the Mogul authorities found it inconvenient to undertake active measures of coercion."
W.H. Moreland, India at the Death of Akbar, 1920

Zamindars had an ability "to establish a claim to sovereignty" largely due to the Mughal Empire's policy of

answers.A: <label>A. religious toleration</label>
answers.B: <label>B. universal taxation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. martial law</label>
answers.D: <label>D. suffrage</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

The Mughal Empire was notable for its religious toleration, (A), a key to success on the subcontinent that was already populated by Hindus. The passage makes it clear that not all zamindars paid taxes, so eliminate (B). Choices (C) and (D) were not characteristic of the Mughal Empire, so eliminate them.

content:
"In Northern India the existence of separate States at this period is usually little more than a question of words. A zamindar who paid revenue to the Mogul was clearly in a position of dependence, and if he wished to establish a claim to sovereignty, the first step was to refuse, or omit to pay revenue. Such an omission might, however, arise from various other causes, and it is probable that in Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur there were numerous chiefs and tribes occupying what constitutional lawyers would regard as an anomalous position, sometimes paying the stipulated revenue, sometimes in open rebellion, and sometimes enjoying practical independence because the Mogul authorities found it inconvenient to undertake active measures of coercion."
W.H. Moreland, India at the Death of Akbar, 1920

Moreland's description of revenue collection in the Mughal Empire is best seen as evidence for which of the following generalizations?

answers.A: <label>A. Only people of certain religions were required to pay revenue to the empire.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Geographical differences may have influenced which groups pay taxes.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Revenue collection was the only source of funds by which the Mughal Empire operated.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The case of Rajputana was a typical one in the Mughal Empire.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

The passage mentions zamindars who lived in areas that the Mughal authorities found "inconvenient" to travel to in order to collect revenue. As the passage notes, these places, such as Raiputana, were anomalous (uncommon), so eliminate (D). The passage does not indicate that tax collection was the only source of revenue, so get rid of (C). Nor is there any mention of whether other religions had to pay taxes or not. Eliminate (A).

content:
"In Northern India the existence of separate States at this period is usually little more than a question of words. A zamindar who paid revenue to the Mogul was clearly in a position of dependence, and if he wished to establish a claim to sovereignty, the first step was to refuse, or omit to pay revenue. Such an omission might, however, arise from various other causes, and it is probable that in Rajputana, Central India, and Chota Nagpur there were numerous chiefs and tribes occupying what constitutional lawyers would regard as an anomalous position, sometimes paying the stipulated revenue, sometimes in open rebellion, and sometimes enjoying practical independence because the Mogul authorities found it inconvenient to undertake active measures of coercion."
W.H. Moreland, India at the Death of Akbar, 1920

The changes experienced by the zamindars under the Mughal throne are most similar to those faced by

answers.A: <label>A. feudal lords under the Holy Roman Empire</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Russian peasants under the Romanovs</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Qing warriors under the Manchu Dynasty</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the daimyo under Emperor Tokugawa</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

For this question, you are looking for a group that had a similar experience to the zamindars. That is, you are looking for a group that had its traditional aristocratic power challenged by a new regime. This would describe the daimyo, (D), in Japan when the Tokugawa Era began. Lords kept their land and relatively important place in society under the Holy Roman Empire, so (A) is not similar to the zamindars. Peasants never had significant power in Russia, so eliminate (B). Choice (C) is not similar because the Qing warriors represented the Manchu Dynasty; eliminate (C).

content:
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325â€“1354 C.E.

Which of the following led directly to the development of the economic system described in the journal?

answers.A: <label>A. Military campaigns</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Meteorological phenomena</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Competition with European trade networks</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The presence of highly developed port cities</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

The Indian Ocean trade network depended primarily on one thing: monsoons. These seasonal wings pushed boats from west to east in one part of the year, and from east to west six months later. The network was driven by the need for trade, not military conquest, so eliminate (A). Choice (C) is incorrect, as there was no competition with Europe. In fact, at the time, the Indian Ocean was far busier a trade route than any route in Europe. The development of the port cities was actually a function of there being a thriving trade network, not a cause of it, so (D) is incorrect. Choice (B) is the answer.

content:
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325â€“1354 C.E.

The views expressed in this journal passage are best seen as evidence of which of the following concerning medieval Islamic societies?

answers.A: <label>A. The absence of religious orthodoxy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Hostility toward outsiders</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Limited economic opportunities</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The supremacy of piety</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The final sentence states that despite the pursuit of wealth, the traders were "pious, humble, [and] upright," which matches (D). The attention to tithes would indicate at least some degree of religious orthodoxy, so eliminate (A). The network welcomed cultures from all over the Indian Ocean, including Zoroastrians and Hindus; eliminate (B). There were vast economic opportunities, so (C) is also incorrect. Choice (D) is the answer.

content:
"I travelled thence to 'Aden, the port of Yemen, on the coast of the ocean. It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325â€“1354 C.E.

The tone of the journal best reflects which of the following developments in the Indian Ocean trade network?

answers.A: <label>A. The ability of commerce to foster cultural diffusion</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The superiority of Arabian port cities</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The increasing difficulty caused by language barriers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The overproduction of cash crops</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

Ibn Batutta focuses on the presence of Indian and Egyptian merchants living in a port city on the Arabian Peninsula. This indicates the presence of cultural diffusion, (A). While this journal passage takes place in Aden, there is no discussion of whether such cities were superior to others along the Indian Ocean, so eliminate (B). The trade network is successful despite the many languages present, so (C) does not make sense. There is no evidence of crop overproduction, so get rid of (D).

content:

It is surrounded by mountains and can be approached from one side only; it has no crops, trees, or water, but has reservoirs in which rainwater is collected. The Arabs often cut off the inhabitants from their supply of drinking-water until the they buy them off with money and pieces of cloth. It is an exceedingly hot place. It is the port of the Indians, and to it come large vessels from Kinbayat [Cambay], Kawlam [Quilon], Calicut and many other Malabar ports [on the south-west coast of India]. There are Indian merchants living there, as well as Egyptian merchants. Its inhabitants are all either merchants, porters, or fishermen. Some of the merchants are immensely rich, so rich that sometimes a single merchant is sole owner of a large ship with all it contains, and this is a subject of ostentation and rivalry amongst them. In spite of that they are pious, humble, upright, and generous in character, treat strangers well, give liberally to devotees, and pay in full the tithes due to God."
Ibn Battuta, ca. 1325â€“1354 C.E.

Ibn Battuta's experiences were LEAST similar to the experiences of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Zheng He</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Marco Polo</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Lorenzo de Medici</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Xuanzang</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

Ibn Batutta was an explorer. Each answer choice is an explorer with the exception of Lorenzo de Medici, who was a statesman from the Italian Renaissance. Therefore, (C) is the answer.

content:
The image below is an American political cartoon
THE ONLY ONE BARRED OUT. Englightened American Statesman. ––"We must draw the line somewhere, you know."
Frank Leslie's illustrated newspaper, 1882

The conflict addressed in the cartoon is best understood in the context of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The imperial interests of the United States</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A dramatic increase in migration</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A stagnation in global trade</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The burgeoning human rights movement</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

The Chinese Exclusion Act was created when the United States wanted to limit access to the Chinese, who had come in search of work. The spike in Chinese immigrants was consistent with much of the world. This increase in migration, (B), was the result of an increased ability to travel, as well as search for more labor opportunities.

content:
The image below is an American political cartoon
THE ONLY ONE BARRED OUT. Englightened American Statesman. ––"We must draw the line somewhere, you know."
Frank Leslie's illustrated newspaper, 1882

Which late-nineteenth/early-twentieth century policy is most similar to the one depicted in the cartoon?

answers.A: <label>A. Open Door Policy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. White Australia Policy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Meiji Restoration</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Russification</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

You are looking for a policy that excluded a particular people from migrating to a particular country. This would be the White Australia Policy, (B), which allowed only English-speaking immigrants (typically from United Kingdom nations) to enter Australia. Eliminate (A), as the Open Door Policy was a trade policy with China. The Meiji Restoration was the process of Japanese modernization by adopting Western influence, so get rid of (C). Russification is not correct, as it refers the process of non-ethnic Russians forced to take on characteristics of Russian culture; eliminate (D).

content:
The image below is an American political cartoon
THE ONLY ONE BARRED OUT. Englightened American Statesman. ––"We must draw the line somewhere, you know."
Frank Leslie's illustrated newspaper, 1882

For which reason does the cartoonist imply that the United States discriminated against Chinese immigrants?

answers.A: <label>A. Fear of overpopulation</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Concerns about Communism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. To avoid competition in the labor market</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Revenge for the Boxer uprising</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

The migrant depicted in the cartoon who is not allowed to enter the United States has a bag called "Industry." This indicates that he is being discriminated against due to his industriousness, which some Americans feared would keep Americans out of jobs. The choice that reflects this idea is (C). The cartoon states that Communists are welcome, so eliminate (B). There is no evidence in the cartoon for either overpopulation or the Boxer Rebellion, so (A) and (D) are incorrect.

content:
The image below is an American political cartoon
THE ONLY ONE BARRED OUT. Englightened American Statesman. ––"We must draw the line somewhere, you know."
Frank Leslie's illustrated newspaper, 1882

Which of the following would the cartoonist argue is an undesirable characteristic in a migrant coming to the United States?

answers.A: <label>A. Temperance</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Racial designation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Industriousness</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Political radicalism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The migrant who carries with him both temperance and industriousness is not allowed in the door. The cartoonist criticizes the American policy for not rewarding these characteristics, which might suggest that the cartoonist favors them. Eliminate (A) and (C). There is no evidence of racial designation, so (B) is incorrect. The cartoonist includes a list of problematic characteristics that Americans seem to have no problem allowing in the country. Many of these characteristics are politically radical, such as Communist, Fenian (Irish radical), and Hoodlum. Therefore, (D) is the answer.

content:
"Indeed, as both the fatwas of distinguished [scholars] who base their opinion on reason and tradition alike and the consensus of the Sunni community agree that the ancient obligation of extirpation, extermination, and expulsion of evil innovation must be the aim of our exalted aspiration, for "Religious zeal is a victory for the Faith of God the Beneficent"; then, in accordance with the words of the Prophet (Peace upon him!) "Whosoever introduces evil innovation into our order must be expelled" and "Whosoever does aught against our order must be expelled," action has become necessary and exigentâ€¦"
Letter from Ottoman Sultan Selim I to Safavid Shah Ismail I, 1514

The letter from Selim I is most clearly an example of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The maintenance of military supremacy at all costs</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Expanding tensions between religious sects</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Factors that brought about the collapse of the Ottoman Empire</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Peacemaking efforts among the Islamic empires</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

At its core, the tensions between Selim and Ismail go back centuries to the initial Sunnia-Shi'a rift. This is apparent in the text when Selim references the fatwa (Islamic religious ruling), as well as the opinions of the Sunni community, against those who "introduce evil" (presumably the Shi'a). Choice (B) is correct.

content:
"Indeed, as both the fatwas of distinguished [scholars] who base their opinion on reason and tradition alike and the consensus of the Sunni community agree that the ancient obligation of extirpation, extermination, and expulsion of evil innovation must be the aim of our exalted aspiration, for "Religious zeal is a victory for the Faith of God the Beneficent"; then, in accordance with the words of the Prophet (Peace upon him!) "Whosoever introduces evil innovation into our order must be expelled" and "Whosoever does aught against our order must be expelled," action has become necessary and exigentâ€¦"
Letter from Ottoman Sultan Selim I to Safavid Shah Ismail I, 1514

The Safavids drew the ire of Islamic empires such as the Ottoman and the Mughal Empires primarily because the Safavids

answers.A: <label>A. were an expansionist empire geographically located between two other expansionists</label>
answers.B: <label>B. rejected the central tenets of Islam</label>
answers.C: <label>C. enslaved Christians, and turned them into Safavid fighters</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Ismail proclaimed himself to be a Caliph</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

The Safavids were located in Persia, smack dab between the Mughal Empire (India) and the Ottoman Empire (Eastern Europe, Northern Africa, and the Levant). This idea matches (A). The Safavids were devout Muslims, so eliminate (B). Choice (C) is incorrect, as it describes a practice utilized by the Ottoman Empire. Choice (D) does not make sense, as Shi'a Muslims would never proclaim there to be a caliph who was not appointed by God from Muhammad's direct family lineage. Selim, by contrast, was named caliph under the Sunni tradition.

content:
"Indeed, as both the fatwas of distinguished [scholars] who base their opinion on reason and tradition alike and the consensus of the Sunni community agree that the ancient obligation of extirpation, extermination, and expulsion of evil innovation must be the aim of our exalted aspiration, for "Religious zeal is a victory for the Faith of God the Beneficent"; then, in accordance with the words of the Prophet (Peace upon him!) "Whosoever introduces evil innovation into our order must be expelled" and "Whosoever does aught against our order must be expelled," action has become necessary and exigentâ€¦"
Letter from Ottoman Sultan Selim I to Safavid Shah Ismail I, 1514

The empire founded by Ismail I can be best characterized by which religious tradition?

answers.A: <label>A. Sufi</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Sikh</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sunni</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Shi'a</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

Persia, since the earliest Muslims lived there, has been largely Shi'a, (D). Accordingly, the Safavid Empire was Shi'a. Selim, the author of the letter, is writing as a Sunni, a group that has long rivaled the Shi'a.

content:
The following image depicts a fourth-century agricultural technique.
Waru Waru, a raised-bed irrigation system, ca. fourth century B.C.E.

Which of the following innovations is LEAST similar to the system depicted in the diagram?

answers.A: <label>A. Chinampas</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Three-field system</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The horse collar</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Tributary system</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

Each answer choice, with the exception of (D), the tributary system (a Chinese system consisting of independent countries acknowledging the supremacy of the Chinese emperor), is an agricultural innovation that boosted production. The chinampas, (A), were fields built on shallow lakes in Mesoamerica. The three-field system, (B), innovated crop rotation in medieval Europe. And the horse collar, (C), was used in many societies through history so that horses would be able to pull ploughs. Therefore, (D) is the answer.

content:
The following image depicts a fourth-century agricultural technique.
Waru Waru, a raised-bed irrigation system, ca. fourth century B.C.E.

Which of the following best explains why human labor took on a greater importance to Andean civilizations than it did in other parts of the world?

answers.A: <label>A. There were not many large enough animals to use as beasts of burden.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Those who could not demonstrate adequate human labor were sacrificed in bloody rituals.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The land was not particularly fertile and therefore required greater efforts to create conditions for crops to grow.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Labor was seen as a great offering to the sun god.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

As with earlier pre-Columbian American civilizations, there was a lack of large animals to use for agricultural labor. Therefore, (A) is correct.

content:
The following image depicts a fourth-century agricultural technique.
Waru Waru, a raised-bed irrigation system, ca. fourth century B.C.E.

Which of the following was NOT a function of Waru Waru?

answers.A: <label>A. Keeping crops safe from animals</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Retaining moisture for crops</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Allowing for more efficient trade</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Minimizing erosion</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

The Waru Waru was characterized by streams of water, which separated crops. Therefore, there was an ever-present water source, which eliminates (B). An added benefit was that it limited animal access to the crops, so eliminate (A). The elevated crop beds also limited the damage caused by erosion during floods, so eliminate (D). Choice (C) is correct.

content:
"The greatest contribution that Africa can make to the peace of the world is to avoid all the dangers inherent in disunity, by creating a political union which will also by its success, stand as an example to a divided world. A Union of African states will project more effectively the African personality. It will command respect from a world that has regard only for size and influence. The scant attention paid to African opposition to the French atomic tests in the Sahara, and the ignominious spectacle of the U.N. in the Congo quibbling about constitutional niceties while the Republic was tottering into anarchy, are evidence of the callous disregard of African Independence by the Great Powers."
Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961

Which of the following explains why Nkrumah feels Africa must "avoid all the dangers inherent in disunity"?

answers.A: <label>A. African nations will not achieve independence without unity.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Disunity is what originally led many African nations into disarray.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The African continent has already experienced its share of civil wars.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The world community sees power as a function of size and influence.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

Nkrumah states that a unified Africa "will command respect from a world that has regard only for size and influence." Most African nations had achieved independence by this point, making (A) incorrect. Choice (B) is incorrect because the disarray of African countries experienced in the middle of the twentieth century stemmed from colonization, not disunity. Choice (C) is unrelated to the point Nkrumah is making, so eliminate it. Choice (D) is the answer.

content:
"The greatest contribution that Africa can make to the peace of the world is to avoid all the dangers inherent in disunity, by creating a political union which will also by its success, stand as an example to a divided world. A Union of African states will project more effectively the African personality. It will command respect from a world that has regard only for size and influence. The scant attention paid to African opposition to the French atomic tests in the Sahara, and the ignominious spectacle of the U.N. in the Congo quibbling about constitutional niceties while the Republic was tottering into anarchy, are evidence of the callous disregard of African Independence by the Great Powers."
Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961

Based on the speech, the French saw Africa as which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. A collection of republics tottering into anarchy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A resource for enhancing French power in the Cold War</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Important due to the Sahara's natural resources</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A strong political union</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

The French used the Algerian desert to test nuclear weapons, which helped advance France's status in the Cold War arms race. Therefore, (B) is the answer.

Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961

The passage is most clearly an example of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Responses to failed unification attempts in Africa</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A plea for the United Nations to intervene in Africa</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A proposal to increase the standing of Africa in the modern world</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Ardent opposition to the influence of capitalism in Africa</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

Nkrumah is presenting a method for Africa to achieve greater standing in the world community. He believes this goal might be realistically attained through unity, which matches (A). There is no reference to failed unification attempts, so eliminate (A). Even though he mentions the United Nations, Nkruma wishes for Africa to find its strength internally, not through outside intervention. Get rid of (B). Choice (D) is incorrect because there is no mention of capitalism in this passage.

content:
"The greatest contribution that Africa can make to the peace of the world is to avoid all the dangers inherent in disunity, by creating a political union which will also by its success, stand as an example to a divided world. A Union of African states will project more effectively the African personality. It will command respect from a world that has regard only for size and influence. The scant attention paid to African opposition to the French atomic tests in the Sahara, and the ignominious spectacle of the U.N. in the Congo quibbling about constitutional niceties while the Republic was tottering into anarchy, are evidence of the callous disregard of African Independence by the Great Powers."
Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961

The inclusion of the Congo in Nkrumah's argument is intended to do which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Demonstrate the possibility of African unity</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Give an example of how African nations are neglected by the world powers</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Present an illustration of how the development of a constitution brings order to nations</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Blame European powers for the difficulties experienced in Africa</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Nkrumah mentions the Congo to illustrate how the world powers do not pay enough attention to the more serious crises in Africa. Choice (B) reflects this idea. Even though he mentions the creation of a constitution in Congo, it is not seen as an orderly nation. Eliminate (C). Choice (A) is incorrect because at the time the Congo did not stand as an example of African unity. Nkrumah's focus is on the possibility of African unity, not on what caused the current situation, which would make (D) incorrect.

content:

The scant attention paid to African opposition to the French atomic tests in the Sahara, and the ignominious spectacle of the U.N. in the Congo quibbling about constitutional niceties while the Republic was tottering into anarchy, are evidence of the callous disregard of African Independence by the Great Powers."
Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanian leader, 1961

Nkrumah's argument in the passage most clearly supports which of the following ideologies?

answers.A: <label>A. Pan-Africanism</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Communism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. African socialism</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Neocolonialism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

Pan-Africanism is the belief that Africans should unite for optimal social, political, and economic outcomes. Use POE to get rid of the other answer choices. Nkrumah stands against all forms of colonialism, so eliminate (D). There is no mention of socialism or communism, so (B) and (C) are incorrect. Choice (A) is the answer.

content:
"The real grievance of the worker is the insecurity of his existence; he is not sure that he will always have work, he is not sure that he will always be healthy, and he foresees that he will one day be old and unfit to work. If he falls into poverty, even if only through a prolonged illness, he is then completely helpless, exam_ins to his own devices, and society does not currently recognize any real obligation towards him beyond the usual help for the poor, even if he has been working all the time ever so faithfully and diligently. The usual help for the poor, however, leaves a lot to be desired, especially in large cities, where it is very much worse than in the country."
Otto von Bismarck, 1884

This speech led to the creation of laws that did which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Limited work hours in factories</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Established public health care and pensions</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Displaced citizens in the overpopulated city to the countryside</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Forced early retirement for aging workers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Otto von Bismarck focuses on the difficulties that both age and poor health present. These concerns gave way to better health care and pensions (payment for retired workers). Therefore, (B) is correct.

content:
"The real grievance of the worker is the insecurity of his existence; he is not sure that he will always have work, he is not sure that he will always be healthy, and he foresees that he will one day be old and unfit to work. If he falls into poverty, even if only through a prolonged illness, he is then completely helpless, exam_ins to his own devices, and society does not currently recognize any real obligation towards him beyond the usual help for the poor, even if he has been working all the time ever so faithfully and diligently. The usual help for the poor, however, leaves a lot to be desired, especially in large cities, where it is very much worse than in the country."
Otto von Bismarck, 1884

Otto von Bismarck likely made this speech in reaction to which of the following issues?

answers.A: <label>A. Social acceptance of child labor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Declining life expectancy in Germany</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Criticisms of German trade tariffs</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Negative effects attributed to industrial capitalism</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

Industrial capitalism has given way to many hardships, some of which are outlined by Otto von Bismarck in this passage. Therefore, (D) is correct. There is no mention of child labor, which had already been addressed decades earlier, so eliminate (A). There is no evidence of a declining life expectancy in Germany. Further, the scientific breakthroughs of the nineteenth century would increase life spans. Eliminate (B). Choice (C) is incorrect because Bismarck never mentions tariffs.

content:
"The real grievance of the worker is the insecurity of his existence; he is not sure that he will always have work, he is not sure that he will always be healthy, and he foresees that he will one day be old and unfit to work. If he falls into poverty, even if only through a prolonged illness, he is then completely helpless, exam_ins to his own devices, and society does not currently recognize any real obligation towards him beyond the usual help for the poor, even if he has been working all the time ever so faithfully and diligently. The usual help for the poor, however, leaves a lot to be desired, especially in large cities, where it is very much worse than in the country."
Otto von Bismarck, 1884

How would twentieth-century economist John Maynard Keynes suggest that society address Otto von Bismarck's evaluation of workers in Germany?

answers.A: <label>A. Keynes would recommend government intervention in order to maintain aggregate demand.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Keynes would suggest helping elderly workers, but claim that the government should not intervene in most circumstances.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Keynes would caution against government intervention in personal economic matters.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Keynes would advocate doing nothing because he felt poverty in rural areas was actually more severe than it was in cities.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

Keynesian economics is critical of the free market's ability to solve all economic problems. Instead, it advocates for governments to create demand (people's ability and willingness to spend money). Choice (A) reflects this idea. If the government can aid in both health-care costs and in post-retirement income, people would have more disposable income to keep the economy healthy. Choices (B), (C), and D) are incorrect because they contradict Keynesian economics.

content:
"The real grievance of the worker is the insecurity of his existence; he is not sure that he will always have work, he is not sure that he will always be healthy, and he foresees that he will one day be old and unfit to work. If he falls into poverty, even if only through a prolonged illness, he is then completely helpless, exam_ins to his own devices, and society does not currently recognize any real obligation towards him beyond the usual help for the poor, even if he has been working all the time ever so faithfully and diligently. The usual help for the poor, however, leaves a lot to be desired, especially in large cities, where it is very much worse than in the country."
Otto von Bismarck, 1884

The long-term effects of Otto von Bismarck's speech include which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Development of socialized programs throughout much of Europe</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Disunity of the German states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Communist overhaul of the eastern parts of Germany</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A decrease in German economic output</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

Throughout the twentieth century, European nations adopted systems to ensure essential needs for its citizensâ€”a type of socialism. Therefore, (A) is correct. Germany stayed unified (and free from a Communist government) until the end of World War II, so eliminate (B) and (C). Germany remained the strongest industrial nation in mainland Europe until World War I, so (D) is incorrect.

content:
Spread of Achaemenid Empire, ca. 6th Century B.C.E.

Which of the following conclusions about the period 600 B.C.E. to 400 B.C.E. is most directly supported by the map?

answers.A: <label>A. The significant contributions of Cyrus II derived from his battles in Egypt.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cambyses focused his military campaigns on the land near the Hindu Kush.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Persians spread their empire outward from their home on the Arabian Peninsula.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Darius I brought the Achaemenid Empire into direct conflict with Greek city-states more than his predecessors did.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The color associated with Darius I touches the Greek city-states, (D). Choice (A) is incorrect because, according to the map, Cyrus II never gained land in Egypt. However, the map shows the land gained by Cambyses II exclusively around Egypt and the Levant. The Hindu Kush borders the Indian subcontinent, so eliminate (B). The Persians' earliest land is on the Persian side of the Persian Gulf, not the Arabian side. Get rid of (C). Choice (D) is the answer.

content:
Spread of Achaemenid Empire, ca. 6th Century B.C.E.

Which empire was most similar to the Achaemenid Empire in its ambition to unify competing states over the course of generations of rulers via a process of centralization?

answers.A: <label>A. Phoenicia</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Han Dynasty</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Gupta Dynasty</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Zhou Dynasty</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Use POE. Phoenicia and the Zhou Dynasty were largely controlled by local groups, so get rid of (A) and (D). The Gupta Dynasty was not effective at centralizing, so eliminate (C). Choice (B) is correct.

content:
Spread of Achaemenid Empire, ca. 6th Century B.C.E.

Which of the following was an important direct effect on Central Asia to derive from the expansion of the Achmaemenid Empire?

answers.A: <label>A. Expansive trade routes were established.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A common religion was required of all citizens.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. East Asian languages and religions became influential.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Cross-cultural commerce became stagnant.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

One of Darius's great accomplishments was the establishment of the Royal Road trade route, which matches (A). This enabled interactions between many cultures in the empire, so (D) is incorrect. The Persians were pretty tolerant of foreign religions, so eliminate (B). The trade routes did not venture too far into East Asia, so there would have been little influence from China and other countries that far to the east. Get rid of (C). The correct answer is (A).

content:
Oh, shame on you, poor Winter King!
What's this that you have done?
Is 't not a very naughty thing
To snatch the kaiser's crown?
Now you will have to stay away
Alike from Rhine and Prague,
And more than that-shame and dismay
Your days and nights will plague.
Right well you knew, and all the world,
Right well they know this thing,
That Ferdinand alone can be
Bohemia's lawful king.
So come, dear Fritz, rouse up and go
To Ferdinand, your king,
And beg him graciously to show
Full pardon for your sin.
"Poor Winter King," seventeenth-century song

Based on the song, the Winter King did which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Gave over his crown to King Ferdinand</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Successfully defended his land from the Holy Roman Empire</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Rebelled against King Ferdinand</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Claimed the lands of Bohemia for the Catholic Church</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

The speaker mentions that the Winter King attempted to "snatch the kaiser's crown." Choice (A) is incorrect because snatching the crown would be to take, not give it over. The song is about Frederick V (referred to as Fritz), a Calvinist king of Bohemia who fought against the Catholic Holy Roman Empire and lost. Therefore, (B) and (D) are incorrect as well and you're left with (C), which is the answer.

Which of the following events inspired the composition of this song?

answers.A: <label>A. Peace of Augsburg</label>
answers.B: <label>B. War of Spanish Succession</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Edict of Nantes</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Thirty Years' War</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

The clues here are mentions of Ferdinand, the Holy Roman Emperor, and the Bohemian king (Ferdinand), which should lead you to the Thirty Years' War, (D).

The narrator of the song would most likely identify as which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. Roman Catholic</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Eastern Orthodox</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Protestant</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Muslim</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

Since the speaker is critical of the actions of the Protestant Frederick and supportive of the Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand, the speaker is likely Catholic. Choice (A) is correct.

Which of the following best explains why the narrator mentions "Rhine and Prague"?

answers.A: <label>A. They are destinations for the Winter King's planned pilgrimage.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. These are lands that the Winter King lost in battle.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Because these were strongholds of the Holy Roman Empire, the narrator warns the Winter King to stay away.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They are significant military posts within the borders of the Holy Roman Empire.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

Rhine and Prague were lands controlled by Frederick before the Thirty Years' War. He lost these in battle with the Holy Roman Empire, hence the speaker's mockery. Therefore, (B) is the answer.

Which of the following is an important underlying issue in this song?

answers.A: <label>A. Rules of royal succession</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Religious conflict</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Military stalemate</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Social class conflicts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

At its core, the Thirty Years' War stems from a longstanding conflict between Catholics and Protestants, which matches (B).

content:
Seizing me, he led me down to the House of Darkness…
To the house where those who enter do not come out,
Along the road of no return,
To the house where those who dwell, do without light,
Where dirt is their drink, their food is of clay…
Where light cannot be seen. They dwell in the dark,
And upon the door and bolt, there lies dust.
from Tablet VII, The Epic of Gilgamesh, Sumeria, ca. 2100 B.C.E.
Truth is good and its worth is lasting.
It has not been disturbed since the day of its creator,
Whereas he who transgresses its ordinances is punished.
It lies as a path in front of even him who knows nothing.
Wrongdoing has never yet brought its venture to port…
Those whom the gods guide cannot lose themselves.
Those to whom they forbid passage will not be able to cross the river of life.
from The Maxims of Ptahhotep, Egypt, ca. 2400 B.C.E.

The above texts are best understood in the context of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The use of religion to justify gender relations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The use of religion to enforce legal norms</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The use of religion to ponder conceptions of the afterlife</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The use of religion to explain social hierarchy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question touches on the various roles played by religion in the societies that adopt them. While religions address all the issues listed in the answers, there is no indication in either text that gender or social status is at stake, and behavior of any kind, legal or otherwise, is not discussed in the first text. Although neither text says so explicitly, each discusses the fate of the soul after death.

content:

from Tablet VII, The Epic of Gilgamesh, Sumeria, ca. 2100 B.C.E.
Truth is good and its worth is lasting.
It has not been disturbed since the day of its creator,

It lies as a path in front of even him who knows nothing.
Wrongdoing has never yet brought its venture to port…
Those whom the gods guide cannot lose themselves.
Those to whom they forbid passage will not be able to cross the river of life.
from The Maxims of Ptahhotep, Egypt, ca. 2400 B.C.E.

The tone of the second text best reflects which of the following hypotheses about the influence of religious beliefs on ancient societies?

answers.A: <label>A. Ancient Egyptian society held compassion up as the highest virtue.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ancient Egyptians believed that moral behavior affected one's fate after death.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ancient Egyptian clergy promoted a strict "eye for an eye" code of ethics.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Ancient Egyptian worshippers committed to an elaborate set of rituals and offerings.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) While compassion and observance of rituals have been held up by many religions as proper behavior, they are not specified in the second text, making A and D weak options. The text speaks of punishment, but not the legal principle of exact retribution, leaving C unlikely. What can be determined safely is that the text means to argue that virtuous and unvirtuous conduct lead to different outcomes in the afterlife.

To the house where those who enter do not come out,
Along the road of no return,

Where light cannot be seen. They dwell in the dark,
And upon the door and bolt, there lies dust.
from Tablet VII, The Epic of Gilgamesh, Sumeria, ca. 2100 B.C.E.
Truth is good and its worth is lasting.
It has not been disturbed since the day of its creator,
Whereas he who transgresses its ordinances is punished.

Those whom the gods guide cannot lose themselves.
Those to whom they forbid passage will not be able to cross the river of life.
from The Maxims of Ptahhotep, Egypt, ca. 2400 B.C.E.

The two texts best support which of the following conclusions?

answers.A: <label>A. Ancient Egyptians had a less gloomy view of the afterlife than ancient Sumerians.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ancient Egyptians were more inclined than ancient Sumerians to view political obedience as morally proper.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ancient Egyptians were more patriarchal in their gender relations than ancient Sumerians.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Ancient Egyptians suffered under a more rigid social hierarchy than ancient Sumerians.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Neither text speaks of gender or social hierarchy, and neither defines what is morally "good," making B, C, and D poor choices. The first text implies that a gloomy afterlife awaits everyone, regardless of how they lead their lives, making it much more fatalistic than the second text, which allows for the possibility of a happier fate.

content:
Know the self to be sitting in the chariot, the body to be the chariot, the intellect the charioteer, and the mind the reins. He who has understanding, who is mindful and always pure, indeed reaches that place from whence he is not born again.
from the Upanishads, India, circa 600sâ€“400s B.C.E.

The excerpt above best reflects which of the following religious propositions?

answers.A: <label>A. Hindus should give up their faith in favor of Buddhism.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Individual responsibility, not priestly authority, brings about spiritual evolution.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. One lifetime is enough to extinguish one's soul after death.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. One's status in the Hindu caste system cannot be altered.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This text metaphorically describes an individual assuming personal control over his or her spiritual destiny. The phrase "that place from whence he is not born again" refers to liberation from the cycle of life, death, and rebirth in which Hindus and Buddhists both believe; no rejection of Buddhism is called for here, and while the text assures the reader that spiritual release can come through one's own actions, it does not promise it after only one lifetime. Although Hindu scriptures justify the caste system (as in D), that is not the subject of this text.

content:
Know the self to be sitting in the chariot, the body to be the chariot, the intellect the charioteer, and the mind the reins. He who has understanding, who is mindful and always pure, indeed reaches that place from whence he is not born again.
from the Upanishads, India, circa 600sâ€“400s B.C.E.

Compared to the message communicated by the excerpt, Buddhist doctrine regarding reincarnation most resembled Hinduism in that it

answers.A: <label>A. retained the concept of karma.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. proposed a heavenly existence after death.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. rejected the validity of all gods.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. mandated unquestioning obedience to the priestly class.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Neither Buddhism nor Hinduism rejected the concept of gods (although some forms of Buddhism minimize their importance), and the text clearly opposes the concept referred to in answer D. Conceptions of the afterlife varied widely among Buddhist denominations, making B doubtful. The notion of karma remained core to both faiths.

content:
Know the self to be sitting in the chariot, the body to be the chariot, the intellect the charioteer, and the mind the reins. He who has understanding, who is mindful and always pure, indeed reaches that place from whence he is not born again.
from the Upanishads, India, circa 600sâ€“400s B.C.E.

Which of the following changes to Indian religious practice took place under the Mauryan emperor Ashoka?

answers.A: <label>A. The rise of Sikhism as a syncretic faith</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The arrival of Islam as a new religion borne by external invaders</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The eradication of traditional Hinduism by armed force</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The official encouragement of Buddhist edicts</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires an understanding of the broader context related to the stimulus material. In this case, knowing the religious trends that unfolded in India during and after the composition of the Upanishads is crucial. A and B took place long after the Mauryan period, while C never happened. Ashoka's religious tolerance and his interest in Buddhism are well-known.

content: Which of the following conclusions about pre-Columbian Mesoamerica is best supported by the information contained in this map?

answers.A: <label>A. The region was governed by a centralized state.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cultures there did not trade extensively.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Much of Mesoamerica was heavily urbanized.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Mesoamerican societies remained isolated from each other.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question requires use of evidence. Be careful in these cases not to pick answers that may be true according to general knowledge, but not proven or indicated by the map (or whatever stimulus material is provided). The map contains no evidence for A, and the directional arrows make B or D unlikely. The proliferation of cities in such a relatively small space makes C the best choice.

content: Which of the following was the clearest sign of mutual cultural influence among the societies depicted on the map?

answers.A: <label>A. The prevalence of human sacrifice and pyramid-building</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Development of a common calendar and system of writing</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A single language shared throughout the region</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Universal adoption of the concept of zero</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires outside information related to the stimulus material, but not referred to directly by it. Knowledge of Mesoamerican societies, most of whose cultures were built on the legacy of the Olmecs, leads most readily to A. Answers B, C, and D are true of some Mesoamerican cultures at certain times, but are not universal enough to satisfy the terms of the question.

content: What goods were most likely to have been traded among the cities shown on the map?

answers.A: <label>A. Corn and beans</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Rice and sugar</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Millet and coffee</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Sorghum and wheat</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) As with the prior question, this requires outside information related to the stimulus material, but not referred to directly by it. The goods listed in B, C, and D are associated more strongly with other parts of the world and in some cases were not available prior to the Columbian Exchange.

content: Which of the following is not among the factors thought by most historians to have played a role in disrupting relations among the Mayan cities included on the map?

answers.A: <label>A. The arrival of European colonizers</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Warfare among major urban centers</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Overpopulation and environmental degradation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Widespread and virulent epidemics</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) While the peoples themselves remained (especially the Maya), the cultures depicted on the map had gone into political decline before the arrival of Spanish conquistadors. The Mesoamerican civilization that confronted Europeans most directly—the Aztecs (or Mexica)—are not shown on the map, further indicating that A is not relevant to the disruption referred to in this question. The downfall of the Maya, Toltecs, and others remains a matter of debate, with B, C, and D among the chief theories proposed for it.

content:
Gunpowder Weaponry: Europe vs. China
In Western Europe during the 1200s through the 1400s, early cannons, as heavy and as slow to fire as they were, proved useful enough in the protracted sieges that dominated warfare during this period that governments found it sufficiently worthwhile to pay for them and for the experimentation that eventually produced gunpowder weapons that were both more powerful and easier to move. By contrast, China, especially after the mid-1300s, was threatened mainly by highly mobile steppe nomads, against whom early gunpowder weapons, with their unwieldiness, proved of little utility. It therefore devoted its efforts to the improvement of horse archer units who could effectively combat the country's deadliest foe.

The argument in this passage most closely relates to which of the following large-scale questions about global history?

answers.A: <label>A. How societies shared strategically important technologies with each other</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Why European states went on to attain military superiority over non-Western powers in the modern era</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Why Silk Road commerce dwindled across the breadth of Eurasia after 1500 C.E.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. How the medieval climatic optimum affected the process of cultural diffusion</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Answer D can be readily dismissed as irrelevant to the text, and C, while somewhat related to the exchange of goods and ideas, is tangential. The technology transfer described in A is not unrelated to the question, but aside from the fact that China did not "share" gunpowder directly or on purpose with Europe, the text is clearly more concerned with the broader historical question addressed by B.

content:
Gunpowder Weaponry: Europe vs. China
In Western Europe during the 1200s through the 1400s, early cannons, as heavy and as slow to fire as they were, proved useful enough in the protracted sieges that dominated warfare during this period that governments found it sufficiently worthwhile to pay for them and for the experimentation that eventually produced gunpowder weapons that were both more powerful and easier to move. By contrast, China, especially after the mid-1300s, was threatened mainly by highly mobile steppe nomads, against whom early gunpowder weapons, with their unwieldiness, proved of little utility. It therefore devoted its efforts to the improvement of horse archer units who could effectively combat the country's deadliest foe.

According to this passage, why did the Chinese, despite inventing gunpowder, fail to lead in the innovation of gunpowder weaponry?

answers.A: <label>A. They were discouraged by Confucian traditionalism from doing so.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. They put too much faith in the numerical strength of their existing armed forces.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They logically decided to develop weapons better suited to their immediate military needs.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They could not afford the initial expense of converting to a new military technology.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question is centered on historical argumentation and historical interpretation, as well as causation. The passage's clear purpose is to show that Chinese lack of interest in early gunpowder weaponry was rational and not culturally or economically short-sighted, as Western historians have traditionally supposed.

It therefore devoted its efforts to the improvement of horse archer units who could effectively combat the country's deadliest foe.

What traditional view of world history does this passage seem to challenge?

answers.A: <label>A. That China has always been less technologically adept than most Afro-Eurasian societies</label>
answers.B: <label>B. That China's rigid form of dictatorial rule suppressed any spirit of military or technological innovation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. That China was hindered by religious fundamentalism when it came to modernizing efforts</label>
answers.D: <label>D. That China was surpassed by Europe in global power because it turned a blind eye to the obvious benefits of technological change</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question, related to the one preceding it, involves historical argumentation even more directly. Answer D relates directly to the earlier view described above.

content:
O ye who believe! Strong drink and games of chance and idols… are only an infamy of Satan's handiwork. Leave it aside in order that ye may succeed.
the Qur'an, Sura 5: 89
When once you hear the roses are in bloom,
Then is the time, my love, to pour the wine.
the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám

Both verses relate most closely to

answers.A: <label>A. key economic processes within Islamic society.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. production of food and drink in Islamic society.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. religious regulation of personal behavior in Islamic society.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. changing gender relations in Islamic society.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) While both texts refer to drink, the production of it (as in B) is not relevant, and gender (as in D) is alluded to only in the second text. Personal behavior, as described in C, is of far more central importance than the economic issues referred to in A.

content:

the Qur'an, Sura 5: 89

Then is the time, my love, to pour the wine.
the Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám

The tone of the first verse best reflects which of the following modes of religious discourse?

answers.A: <label>A. A puritanical injunction to adhere to a strict code of conduct</label>
answers.B: <label>B. An ecumenical call for religious tolerance</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A sermon about respecting political authority</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A spirited attempt to convert non-believers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) By forbidding strong drink and gambling, this passage from the Qu'ran is clearly trying to regulate how individuals conduct themselves.
