A comparison of both verses would best support which of the following conclusions?

answers.A: <label>A. Many Muslims inclined toward atheism in the premodern era.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Religious restrictions were not universally observed by all Muslims.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Christian missionaries were steadily winning converts among Muslim populations.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Muslim intellectuals were generally hostile to traditional religious practice.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question calls for contextualization, historical argumentation, and historical interpretation. The passage from the Qur'an presents a cultural norm that religious doctrine sought to enforce—in this case Islam's famous restriction on the consumption of alcohol—while the second indicates that the restriction was not always observed in real life.

content:
Troop strength of the army of the British East India Company, 1793â€“1815

The information presented in the chart above is best interpreted in light of which of the following contexts?

answers.A: <label>A. Colonial efforts to transfer technological skills to native populations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Colonial attempts to mobilize military strength overseas</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Colonial desires to inculcate Western values among native troops</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Colonial intentions to segregate white colonizers from native inhabitants</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question focuses on techniques used by colonizing states to maintain imperial presence abroad. Answers A, C, and D address concerns acted upon by colonial administrators, but they are unconnected to the military matters connected with the recruitment and training of sepoys, or native Indian troops, to supplement the British troops that could be sent over by the British East India Company.

content:
Troop strength of the army of the British East India Company, 1793â€“1815

Which of the following most likely motivated the policy whose operation the above chart depicts?

answers.A: <label>A. The provision of training for British troops in a colonial setting</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The instillation of patriotic pride among Indians by allowing them to serve as soldiers</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The minimizing of the cost of maintaining imperial authority abroad</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The separation of white soldiers from native troops</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question requires use of evidence and historical interpretation, and it also involves causation. If A were true, the number of British troops in India might be expected to rise over time, and there is no evidence in the chart to indicate that B or D were priorities (even though mixing between Europeans and natives was discouraged). Answer C touches on a money-saving strategy used widely by most colonial powers.

content:
Troop strength of the army of the British East India Company, 1793–1815

The policy depicted in the chart above left British colonial authority particularly vulnerable during which of the following events?

answers.A: <label>A. The Salt March of 1930</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Second and Third Maratha Wars of 1803–1818</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Amritsar Massacre of 1919</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Indian Revolt of 1857</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires knowledge related to the stimulus material, but beyond what is presented in it. In this case, understanding of the aftermath is crucial. Answers A and C are very long-term consequences associated with the Indian independence movement of the 1900s, and have nothing to do with sepoys. Sepoys helped the British to win the wars mentioned in B. It was during the revolt described in D that the sepoys' expertise in Western ways of war (and their large numbers) threatened to topple British colonial authority.

content: The image above is best understood as an example of which of the following trends?

answers.A: <label>A. Religious fundamentalism</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Transnational migration</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Non-violent decolonization</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Economic globalization</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This McDonald's sign is instantly recognizable, despite the words' having been translated into Arabic. The global prominence of a company that originated in the United States is a classic hallmark of the trend described in D. (The formation of transnational corporations—another topic of interest in the AP World History course—would also have been an acceptable answer, had it been an option.)

content: Which of the following can be seen as the most reasonable explanation for the development shown in the image above?

answers.A: <label>A. U.S. military domination over the Middle East</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Foreign takeover of U.S. corporations</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Cultural autonomy in the non-Western world</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The global influence of U.S. mass culture</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question relies on use of evidence and historical interpretation. Answer A refers to "hard" power (enforced by military and geopolitical might) rather than the "soft" power associated with cultural and economic influence. While answer B refers to a trend that has unfolded in many parts of the Third World, it generally involves the nationalization and transformation of Western corporations. Answer C would imply no role at all in the Western world for a corporation like McDonalds, so D is left as the correct answer.

content:
Leonard Parkinson, Maroon resistance fighter, Jamaica, ca. 1796
Map of major Cossack hosts of the former Russian Empire

Taken together, both images are best understood in which of the following contexts?

answers.A: <label>A. Societies consisting of refugees from slave status</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Societies practicing a schismatic religion</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Societies governed by warrior elites</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Societies existing on the periphery of large states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) While A applies to the first image, and while C could be interpreted as applying to the second, neither applies to both. There is nothing to indicate any connection to religious faith in either image. The key historical trend at play here is the formation of societies on the frontiers or edges of larger nations.

content:
Leonard Parkinson, Maroon resistance fighter, Jamaica, ca. 1796
Map of major Cossack hosts of the former Russian Empire

Which historical development contributed most to the formation of the society associated with the first image?

answers.A: <label>A. The Atlantic slave trade</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The flow of refugees caused by the Seven Years' War</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The segregation of races imposed by British colonial authorities</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The migratory patterns encouraged by the arrival of smallpox from Europe</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not explicitly depicted in it. Here, background is pertinent. Maroon societies in Latin America, the Caribbean, and the Gulf of Mexico formed around communities of escaped slaves brought over from Africa.

content:
Leonard Parkinson, Maroon resistance fighter, Jamaica, ca. 1796
Map of major Cossack hosts of the former Russian Empire

Which of the following statements is most solidly supported by the information contained in the map shown in the second image?

answers.A: <label>A. Cossack communities devoutly adhered to a conservative strain of Russian Orthodox Christianity.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cossack hosts frequently rebelled against the centralizing authority of the Russian Empire.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Cossack military units consisted of highly skilled horseback warriors.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Cossack ethnic identity was shaped by intermarriage with non-Russian peoples on the empire's frontiers.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires you to avoid drawing conclusions that cannot be supported by information from the stimulus material. Answers A, B, and C are all factually correct, but nothing in the second image would allow you to draw those conclusions. The location of Cossack communities on non-Russian frontiers makes D a reasonable answer.

content:
Leonard Parkinson, Maroon resistance fighter, Jamaica, ca. 1796
Map of major Cossack hosts of the former Russian Empire

The ultimate fate of the societies depicted in both images was

answers.A: <label>A. to win their full independence.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. to be hunted down and eradicated.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. to be absorbed by the states neighboring them.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. to migrate to distant territories elsewhere.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question likewise requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not explicitly depicted in it, but is focused instead on aftermath and consequences. The broad historical context here involves the gradual incorporation of peripheral societies into more centralized states.

content:
In fact, the peculiar aggravation of the Cawnpore massacres was this, that the deed was done by a subject race â€” by black men who dared to shed the blood of their masters, and that of poor helpless ladies and children. Here we had not only a servile war, but we had a war of religion, a war of race, and a war of revenge, of hope, of national promptings to shake off the yoke of a stranger, and to re-establish the full power of native chiefs, and the full sway of native religions. Whatever the causes of the mutiny and the revolt, it is clear enough that one of the modes by which the leaders, as if by common instinct, determined to effect their end was, the destruction of every white man, woman or child who fell into their hands.
British journalist William Howard Russell, My Indian Mutlny Diary, 1860
Violence, it must be emphasized, was an essential component of the British presence in India. A dominant power is always uneasy with violence directed against it. The right to violence is, therefore, everywhere a privilege that authority enjoys and refuses to share with those under it: power always insists on violence as its exclusive monopoly. British rule in India, as an autocracy, had meticulously constructed a monopoly of violence. The revolt of 1857 shattered that monopoly by matching an official, alien violence by an indigenous violence of the colonized. The bodies of the British had acquired certain dignities in India that were predestined by birth and by the colour of their skin. This was the condition of their domination, of their superiority: rulers and ruled were arranged hierarchically as superior and inferior races, as civilized and uncivilized. And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990

The passages above can best be connected with which of the following forms of violence?

answers.A: <label>A. Banditry due to socio-economic breakdown</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Killing of civilians during wartime</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Collateral damage caused by weapons of mass destruction</label>
answers.D: <label>D. State-sponsored campaigns of genocide</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Answers C and D belong to a later time period than that covered by the texts, and both texts speak of a more systematic type of violence than banditry. Wars in the modern era have seen a steady upswing in the rate of civilian casualties.

content:

From the perspective of the first passage, the death of British citizens at Cawnpore

answers.A: <label>A. seems to mark a betrayal of a "higher" race by a "lesser" race.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. should be seen as a regrettable but avoidable mistake.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. can be said to have been brought on by the British themselves.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. was seen by those who killed them as a religious duty.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires contextualization and the interpretation of a particular point of view. The author, a British reporter who lived at the time in question, would have been likely to sympathize with his compatriots, and also to share the prejudices common to his time and place, including a sense of racial superiority over darker-skinned peoples. Nothing in the passage speaks to answers B, C, or D.

According to the second passage, the Cawnpore Massacre

answers.A: <label>A. was justifiable according to local military custom, even if it violated Western military norms.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. can be viewed as a reaction to the systemic brute force with which the British governed India.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. should be praised as a brave patriotic blow against British colonial oppression.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. seems to have been the product of a well-organized and long-premeditated conspiracy.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question also requires interpretation of a point of view, and also touches on historiographical issues. The author here is an academic historian, and also from India. He does not excuse the Cawnpore Massacre, but his purpose is to place it in a larger context of mutual violence and disrespect. In his view, the British did not "deserve" to suffer violence, but neither were they blameless for the mass outbreak of brutality.

And this superiority manifested itself by denying to the Indians a "humanness"; by treating them and conceiving of them as animals.
Rudrangshu Mukherjee, "The Kanpur [Cawnpore] Massacres in India in the Revolt of 1857," 1990

In the short term, the events discussed in both passages led to which of the following outcomes?

answers.A: <label>A. The expulsion of the British East India Company and partial home rule for India</label>
answers.B: <label>B. British victory over Indian rebels and the strengthening of the British East India Company</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Indian military success and the attainment of full independence from British authority</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The defeat of Indian rebels and the imposition of direct rule by the British government</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires contextualization and knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not referred to directly by it. The direct aftermath of the Indian Revolt was the suppression of the sepoy rebels and the assumption of colonial authority by the British crown, as opposed to the British East India Company.

content:
WORLD GDP, 1600â€“1870 (in millions of dollars, calculated to 1990 value)

According to the chart above, which of the following experienced the highest rate of economic growth, as measured by share of world GDP, between 1600 and 1870?

answers.A: <label>A. India</label>
answers.B: <label>B. China</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Western Europe</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Great Britain</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question focuses on the interpretation of data. Rate of growth means change at the fastest pace, which may or may not correlate with growth in absolute terms (the actual amount from year to year). Although Great Britain's raw numbers are lower than those for other parts of the world, the extent of change from year to year is extremely high. To move from 1.8% to 2.88% represents much faster growth than to move from 20% to 22.5%, for example.

content:
WORLD GDP, 1600â€“1870 (in millions of dollars, calculated to 1990 value)

Which of the following best describes economic trends in China during the timespan covered in the chart?

answers.A: <label>A. China's economy steadily shrank in absolute terms and as a percentage of world GDP.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. China's economy gained ground relative to Western Europe's in absolute terms but not proportionally to world GDP.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. China's economy grew in absolute terms but shrank as a percentage of world GDP.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. China's economy lost ground to India's in absolute terms and proportionally to world GDP.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question also relies on interpretation of data. Answer A is false, because China's GDP was higher in 1870 than in 1600 (even though it experienced a dip in 1700), and B is false because its GDP was lower than Western Europe's both in absolute terms and as a percentage of global GDP. Answer D can be easily proven incorrect as well.

content:
WORLD GDP, 1600–1870 (in millions of dollars, calculated to 1990 value)

Which of the following had an important direct effect on the economic developments depicted in the chart?

answers.A: <label>A. The abolition of the Atlantic slave trade in the 1800s</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The rise of Chinese naval power in the 1700s</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The industrialization of European economies in the 1700s and 1800s</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The revival of Silk Road trade in the 1600s and 1700s</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question calls for contextualization by calling on knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not directly referred to by it. Answers B and D refer to trends that did not in fact occur, while A—as economically important as the abolition of slavery was—would not have affected patterns of GDP growth as profoundly as industrialization.

content:
WORLD GDP, 1600â€“1870 (in millions of dollars, calculated to 1990 value)

Which of the following factors would have had the most significant impact on economic developments in India during the timespan covered in the chart?

answers.A: <label>A. The global silver glut caused by Spanish mining in the Americas</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The growing demand in South Asia for Chinese tea and silk</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The expanding commercial influence of the British East India Company</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The adoption of the gold standard by European and North American states</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question also calls for knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not referred to directly by it. In the 1600s, the British East India Company had only a few footholds in India; its imprint on India had grown significantly by 1700, and by 1870, all of India had been directly colonized by Great Britain. Answer B did not occur, while A and D would have had a minor impact at best on Indian economic growth.

British economic interactions with India during the timespan covered in the chart would have been chiefly concerned with which of the following commodities?

answers.A: <label>A. Cotton</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Spices</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Ivory</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Opium</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Likewise, this question calls for knowledge related to the stimulus material. Understanding the importance of Indian cotton as a trade commodity is key to contextualizing this question.

content:
An Act to place certain restrictions on Immigration and to provide for the removal from the Commonwealth of Prohibited Immigrants.
…
3. The immigration into the Commonwealth of the persons described in any of the following paragraphs in this section (hereinafter called "prohibited immigrants") is prohibited, namely
(a) Any person who when asked to do so by an officer fails to write out at dictation and sign in the presence of the officer a passage of fifty words in length in a European language directed by the officer;
(b) Any person in the opinion of the Minister or of an officer to become a charge upon the public or upon any public or charitable organisation;
…
(g) Any persons under a contract or agreement to perform manual labour within the Commonwealth: Provided that this paragraph shall not apply to workmen exempted by the Minister for special skill required by Australia…
Immigration Restriction Act of 1901 (Australia)
Whereas in the opinion of the Government of the United States the coming of Chinese laborers to this country endangers the good order of certain localities within the territory thereof;
Therefore,
Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That from and after the expiration of ninety days next after the passage of this act, the coming of Chinese laborers to the United States be suspended; and during such suspension it shall not be lawful for any Chinese laborer to come, or having so come after the expiration of said ninety days to remain within the United States.
SEC. 2. That the master of every vessel who shall knowingly bring within the United States on such vessel, and land or permit to be landed, any Chinese laborer, from any foreign port or place, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars for each and every such Chinese laborer so brought, and may be also imprisoned for a term not exceeding one year….
Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 (United States)

The passages are best seen as examples of which prominent social or economic trend from the 1800s?

answers.A: <label>A. The rise of anti-Semitic ideologies</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Trade protectionism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A growing desire to attract skilled labor from abroad</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Hardening of anti-immigrant sentiment</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) All of the answers describe modern trends in social and economic history. Answers B and C could be seen as tangentially related to the texts, but D is more directly connected to them. Anti-Semitism, described in A, was on the rise during this time period—and had an impact on immigration policies—but did not specifically motivate either of these laws.

The first passage can be regarded as the cornerstone of which of the following official initiatives?

answers.A: <label>A. The White Australia Policy</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The Commonwealth Literacy Crusade</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Australian Economic Diversification Program</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Australian Migrant Exclusion Campaign</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question involves contextualization and requires knowledge related to the stimulus material without being explicitly referred to by it. Answer A is the infamous policy line inaugurated by the law excerpted in the first passage.

The emphasis on language in the first passage is most safely interpreted as

answers.A: <label>A. a concern for high educational standards in a rapidly growing society.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a tactic allowing the exclusion of non-Europeans without referring directly to race.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a measure to ensure that all immigrants possessed useful expertise.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an attempt to bar all immigrants regardless of origin.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) For the most part, the White Australia Policy sought to exclude Asians without saying so overtly. The emphasis on language allowed the authorities to enact a fundamentally racist policy while claiming only to be concerned with skills and education.

Which of the following economic activities did the most to drive the rising levels of immigration that led to the enactment of the law described in the second passage?

answers.A: <label>A. Railroad construction</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Fertilizer harvesting</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Sugarcane production</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Gold mining</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Again, this question requires understanding of context and knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not specifically mentioned by it. Chinese immigrants to the Americas worked in a number of economic sectors, including those alluded to in B, C, and D, but in the United States (and Canada), large numbers worked on railroads.

What broad trend from the 1800s formed the background for the enactment of the laws described in both passages?

answers.A: <label>A. The growing appeal of Christianity among Indian and Chinese populations</label>
answers.B: <label>B. European and American colonial domination of India and China</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Pacific-wide migration of Indian and Chinese indentured laborers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Gradual industrialization of the Indian and Chinese economies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question focuses on contextualization. The AP topic most directly connected to the documents at hand is that described in C.

content:
No task is more urgent than that of preserving peace. Without peace our independence means little. The rehabilitation and upbuilding of our countries will have little meaning. Our revolutions will not be allowed to run their course. What can we do? We can do much! We can inject the voice of reason into world affairs. We can mobilize all the spiritual, all the moral, all the political strength of Asia and Africa on the side of peace. Yes, we! We, the peoples of Asia and Africa, 1.4 billion strong.
Indonesian leader Sukarno, keynote address to the Bandung Conference, 1955

The passage above is most associated with which of the following developments?

answers.A: <label>A. The formation of the non-aligned movement</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Global disarmanent and nuclear non-proliferation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Green Revolution in agriculture</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Mobilization of pan-Asian ideology</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question tests contextualization and historical knowledge. Sukarno is not speaking of agriculture or nuclear weapons, so B and C are not likely choices. While he was interested in advancing Asian interests, his appeal at the Bandung Conference was aimed more widely than D would suggest. The Bandung Conference was a hallmark moment in the creation of the "third-world" non-aligned movement, making A the best answer.

content:
No task is more urgent than that of preserving peace. Without peace our independence means little. The rehabilitation and upbuilding of our countries will have little meaning. Our revolutions will not be allowed to run their course. What can we do? We can do much! We can inject the voice of reason into world affairs. We can mobilize all the spiritual, all the moral, all the political strength of Asia and Africa on the side of peace. Yes, we! We, the peoples of Asia and Africa, 1.4 billion strong.
Indonesian leader Sukarno, keynote address to the Bandung Conference, 1955

The "revolutions" spoken of by Sukarno in the passage above most likely relate to which of the following causes?

answers.A: <label>A. Gender equality</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Communism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Decolonization</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Environmental conservation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) The broad historical context related to this question is the postwar success of national-liberation efforts in the so-called "third world." Between the 1940s and the 1970s, colonial possessions in Africa, Asia, and elsewhere freed themselves in a massive wave of decolonization, making C the best answer.

content:
No task is more urgent than that of preserving peace. Without peace our independence means little. The rehabilitation and upbuilding of our countries will have little meaning. Our revolutions will not be allowed to run their course. What can we do? We can do much! We can inject the voice of reason into world affairs. We can mobilize all the spiritual, all the moral, all the political strength of Asia and Africa on the side of peace. Yes, we! We, the peoples of Asia and Africa, 1.4 billion strong.
Indonesian leader Sukarno, keynote address to the Bandung Conference, 1955

Like numerous other leaders in Africa, Asia, and the Middle East, Sukarno attempted, but did not completely succeed, in maintaining a neutral stance during

answers.A: <label>A. the Arab-Israeli conflict.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. the Korean War.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the Cold War.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the Vietnam conflicts.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) To leaders like Sukarno, Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, Gamal Nasser of Egypt, and Jawaharlal Nehru of India, "non-alignment" meant neutrality during the Cold War. Suspicious of the Western powers that had colonized so much of the world, and also distrustful of the USSR, "third-world" nations often tried to remain at arms' length from both. However, most ended up trading with, or even forming military alliances with, one or the other, especially if they wanted assistance with modernization efforts or in local wars against neighboring countries.

content:
Now if divorce is your wish, I cannot blame you. For the waiting has been long. And I do not know whether the Creator will grant relief immediately so that I can come home, or whether matters will take time, for I cannot come home with nothing. Now the matter is in your hand. If you wish to end our marriage, accept this bill of repudiation, and you are free. May God inspire you with the right decision.
Letter from a Jewish trader in India to his wife in Cairo, ca. 1200

The passage above is best seen in light of which of the following historical developments?

answers.A: <label>A. The formation of far-flung diaspora communities as a result of interregional commerce</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The continued use of organized religion to justify patriarchy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The permanent division of families due to armed conflict along established trade routes</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The evolution of family structure among polytheistic populations</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Judaism is a monotheistic religion, making D incorrect, and while Judaism can be considered patriarchal, nothing in the letter speaks to this, making B unlikely. Family separation is clearly at stake, but there is no talk of war in the letter, making A (which speaks to a key AP topic) a better choice than C.

content:
Now if divorce is your wish, I cannot blame you. For the waiting has been long. And I do not know whether the Creator will grant relief immediately so that I can come home, or whether matters will take time, for I cannot come home with nothing. Now the matter is in your hand. If you wish to end our marriage, accept this bill of repudiation, and you are free. May God inspire you with the right decision.
Letter from a Jewish trader in India to his wife in Cairo, ca. 1200

Which of the following is the most probable cause of the marital strain evident in the passage above?

answers.A: <label>A. The strain placed on merchant families by long periods of separation</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Religious disagreements arising from the merchant's exposure to Hinduism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A decision on the part of the merchant to remain permanently in India</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Bankruptcy stranding the merchant far from home</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question calls for interpretation and close reading of evidence. Nothing in the letter gives any support to B, C, or D. Diaspora communities frequently experienced the strains of long-term separation from loved ones.

content:
African hunters harvesting elephant ivory, Belgian Congo, ca. 1880s

The image above most likely depicts which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. African hunters pursuing their traditional livelihood</label>
answers.B: <label>B. African hunters exploiting resources under orders from colonial masters</label>
answers.C: <label>C. African hunters engaged in trade with Westerners on equal terms</label>
answers.D: <label>D. African hunters taking charge of ivory harvesting to keep whites from depleting supplies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question requires knowledge of broad trends and the ability to contextualize them. Answer C is unlikely in an era when Africa was so thoroughly colonized, and neither the pursuit of traditional hunting (as in A) nor the attempt to harvest ivory against white interests (as in D) would likely be captured by Western photography. Forcing natives to exploit local resources was an all-too-common practice in colonial regimes, making B the best answer.

content:
African hunters harvesting elephant ivory, Belgian Congo, ca. 1880s

Which of the following resources would have been pursued even more intensely in the colony depicted in the above image?

answers.A: <label>A. Gold</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Cinnamon</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Rubber</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Diamonds</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not referred to directly by it. The commodity most prized by colonial officials in the Belgian Congo was rubber. Gold and diamonds were more important elsewhere in Africa, especially in the south.

content:
African hunters harvesting elephant ivory, Belgian Congo, ca. 1880s

In which of the following ways can the above image most reasonably be faulted for providing an incomplete view of how the colony in question was administered?

answers.A: <label>A. It fails to show the notorious mutilations inflicted by Belgian overseers on workers who fell short of quotas.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It omits the lived experience of village women under Belgian colonial rule.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It gives little indication of the complex social stratification that prevailed during the Belgian colonial era.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It shows nothing of the way Belgian authorities deliberately encouraged racial tensions between neighboring tribal groups.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires historiographical thinking, and also outside knowledge related to the stimulus material. The brutality of colonial administration in the Belgian Congo was notorious, even by the standard of the day, and while the photograph gives no hint of it, workers—especially on rubber plantations—suffered terrible beatings and amputations for failure to fulfill work quotas.

content:
Meng Yizi asked about the treatment of parents. The Master said, "Never disobey!" When Fan Chi was driving his carriage for him, [he asked], "In what sense did you mean this?" The Master said, "While they are alive, serve them according to proper ritual. When they die, bury them according to proper ritual, and sacrifice to them according to proper ritual."
Confucius, The Analects, Book 2, Chapter 5

Which of the following ideals does the passage above exemplify?

answers.A: <label>A. Filial piety</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Forgiveness of wrongdoings</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Respect for honesty and moderation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Monotheistic worship</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question calls for interpretation and close reading. The text's emphasis on the obedience and respect due to one's parents—a core tenet of Confucianism—makes A by far the best answer.

content:
Meng Yizi asked about the treatment of parents. The Master said, "Never disobey!" When Fan Chi was driving his carriage for him, [he asked], "In what sense did you mean this?" The Master said, "While they are alive, serve them according to proper ritual. When they die, bury them according to proper ritual, and sacrifice to them according to proper ritual."
Confucius, The Analects, Book 2, Chapter 5

In China and the regions it influenced, Confucian teachings like the one above were used politically for which of the following purposes?

answers.A: <label>A. To motivate charitable works</label>
answers.B: <label>B. To justify war against neighboring states</label>
answers.C: <label>C. To achieve gender equality</label>
answers.D: <label>D. To reinforce social hierarchy</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not referred to directly by it. Confucianism held up the properly functioning family as a model for society as a whole. Social hierarchy was therefore justified, and Chinese rulers found this ideology extremely useful as a way of encouraging obedience and respect for political authority.

content:
New York! I say New York, let black blood flow into your blood.
Let it wash the rust from your steel joints, like an oil of life
Let it give your bridges the curve of hips and supple vines…
See your rivers stirring with musk alligators
And sea cows with mirage eyes…
Just open your eyes to the April rainbow
And your eyes, especially your ears, to God
Who in one burst of saxophone laughter
Created heaven and earth in six days,
And on the seventh slept a deep Negro sleep.
Senegalese poet Léopold Sédar Senghor, "To New York," 1956

The verse above is best seen as belonging to which of the following modern cultural developments?

answers.A: <label>A. The triumph of avant-garde literary styles over traditional realism</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The adaptation of Western literary forms by non-Western authors</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The political use of art and literature for propagandistic purposes</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The response of interwar literary figures to the horrors of World War I</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Politics and war appear to be absent from this poem, making C and D unlikely choices. While the style can be viewed as modernist, making answer A possible, the fact that an African poet is writing in a form very much associated with Western literature makes B an even better response.

Which of the following trends is likeliest to have inspired the imagery in the accompanying verse?

answers.A: <label>A. The Romantic movement</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The emergence of Surrealism</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The rise of mass media</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Jazz Age</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question calls for the contextualization of the stimulus material. Romanticism and Surrealism precede the 1950s, and neither suit the tone of the poem. Modern music could be seen to have some connection to mass media, but the references to "blackness"—Senghor is a key figure in the Négritude movement—and saxophones are best associated with the Harlem Renaissance and the Jazz Age.

content:
New York! I say New York, let black blood flow into your blood.
Let it wash the rust from your steel joints, like an oil of life
Let it give your bridges the curve of hips and supple vines…
See your rivers stirring with musk alligators
And sea cows with mirage eyes…
Just open your eyes to the April rainbow
And your eyes, especially your ears, to God
Who in one burst of saxophone laughter
Created heaven and earth in six days,
And on the seventh slept a deep Negro sleep.
Senegalese poet Léopold Sédar Senghor, "To New York," 1956

Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of an African poet writing so lyrically about New York?

answers.A: <label>A. Outmigration from Africa due to political violence</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Stronger transatlantic influences linking art in Afro-Eurasia with that in the Americas</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Preference on the part of African intellectuals for Western cultural advancements</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Lack of a rich indigenous artistic tradition in Africa</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) Nothing in the verse gives evidence for A (and neither does basic knowledge of the the Négritude poets), and D is based on a factual falsity. While non-Western intellectuals became interested in using Western artistic forms, it did not necessarily mean they preferred them, making B a better answer than C.

Literacy Rate
1897  24%
1917  45%
1926  56%
1937  75%
1939  81.10%
1955  99.90%
Source: Census data and Soviet Ministry of Education

The information presented in the above chart is best understood in which of the following historical contexts?

answers.A: <label>A. Educational reform in the modern era</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Centralized and state-directed campaigns of modernization</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Experimentation with syndicalist forms of socio-economic organization</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Second-stage industrialization in the non-Western world</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question calls for contextualization. Answer C has to do with fascist economics, and the industrialization spoken of in D has little to do with the chart's subject. Answer A is obviously related to the subject and may seem correct. However, modernization, as in B, is a larger and more profound historical trend, and directly related to the history of the USSR, a highly centralized state.

Which of the following segments of the Russian/Soviet population would probably have benefited most from the rising literacy rates depicted in the chart?

answers.A: <label>A. The rural peasantry</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Members of the Russian Orthodox clergy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The urban middle class</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Officers in the armed forces</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The social groups described in B, C, and D would all tend to have relatively high rates of literacy. Regardless of nationality, rural populations have generally be slowest to benefit from the spread of education and the creation of school systems.

A historian sympathetic to Soviet communism would most likely use the chart as evidence to support which of the following propositions?

answers.A: <label>A. The ideals of the Russian Revolution were betrayed by the Leninist and Stalinist regimes.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Lenin and Stalin vastly improved Russian military preparedness.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Communism has been made to work more efficiently in Russia than in China.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Despite abuses on the part of Lenin and Stalin, the Soviet regime managed significant achievements.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question is related to historiography and argumentation. Soviet and Russian historians have made arguments similar to those in B and C, and have even—in some cases—agreed with A. However, the pro-Soviet argument that best relates to the improvement of literacy rates is described in D.

content:
Whether the question be to continue or to discontinue the practice of sati, the decision is equally surrounded by an awful responsibility. To consent to the consignment year after year of hundreds of innocent victims to a cruel and untimely end, when the power exists of preventing it, is a predicament which no conscience can contemplate without horror. But, on the other hand, to put to hazard by a contrary course the very safety of the British Empire in India is an alternative which itself may be considered a still greater evil. When we had powerful neighbours and greater reason to doubt our own security, expediency might recommend a more cautious proceeding, but now that we are supreme my opinion is decidedly in favour of an open and general prohibition.
William Bentinck, Govenor-General of India, "On the Suppression of Sati," 1829
I have made it my study to examine the nature and character of the Indians [who trade with us], and however repugnant it may be to our feelings, I am convinced they must be ruled with a rod of iron, to bring and keep them in a proper state of subordination, and the most certain way to effect this is by letting them feel their dependence on [the foodstuffs and manufactured goods we sell them].
George Simpson, Head of Northern Department, Hudson's Bay Company, 1826

The passages above are best understood in the context of which of the following practices?

answers.A: <label>A. Legalization of slavery in overseas colonies</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Exercise of colonial administrative power over native peoples</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Western missionary efforts in colonized territories</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Mobilization of military resources from colonial possessions</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question calls for interpretive skill and the ability to place the documents in broader historical context. Answers A and D have little to do with either text. While religious practices are alluded to in the first document, they are not in the second, making C less relevant. Both have to do with imperial governance of native peoples, as in B.

content:
Whether the question be to continue or to discontinue the practice of sati, the decision is equally surrounded by an awful responsibility. To consent to the consignment year after year of hundreds of innocent victims to a cruel and untimely end, when the power exists of preventing it, is a predicament which no conscience can contemplate without horror. But, on the other hand, to put to hazard by a contrary course the very safety of the British Empire in India is an alternative which itself may be considered a still greater evil. When we had powerful neighbours and greater reason to doubt our own security, expediency might recommend a more cautious proceeding, but now that we are supreme my opinion is decidedly in favour of an open and general prohibition.
William Bentinck, Govenor-General of India, "On the Suppression of Sati," 1829
I have made it my study to examine the nature and character of the Indians [who trade with us], and however repugnant it may be to our feelings, I am convinced they must be ruled with a rod of iron, to bring and keep them in a proper state of subordination, and the most certain way to effect this is by letting them feel their dependence on [the foodstuffs and manufactured goods we sell them].
George Simpson, Head of Northern Department, Hudson's Bay Company, 1826

The tone of the first passage best supports which of the following suppositions about British motivations for eradicating the sati ritual?

answers.A: <label>A. The British intended principally to Christianize India's Hindu population.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The British sought to end what they considered an inhumane practice without endangering their own authority.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. They acted out of a progressive concern for women's equality.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. They were impelled by a racially prejudiced disdain for all Indian customs.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question involves use of evidence and historical interpretation. As the leading official in a joint-stock company operating under a government charter, Bentinck was concerned above all with profits and the maintenance of British power, as in B. He was only moved to act on his moral and religious convictions once his main priorities were met. The BEIC actively discouraged—but did not prevent—Christian missionary activity, and it often ignored local customs it found objectionable, precisely because it understood how native discontent might destabilize its position. So A and D are incorrect, and Bentinck, although seemingly sincere in disliking the deaths of women caused by sati, gives no indication that he favored women's equality.

George Simpson, Head of Northern Department, Hudson's Bay Company, 1826

Which of the following resources would the author of the second passage have been most likely interested in obtaining from local natives?

answers.A: <label>A. Ivory</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Tobacco</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Silver</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Furs</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires contextualization and knowledge related to the stimulus material, even if not directly referred to by it. The Hudson's Bay Company had many economic interests in Canada, but the fur trade was paramount during the time period in question.

The first passage can be said to undermine which commonly held assumption about Western imperialism?

answers.A: <label>A. That European colonizers sometimes interfered with native religious practices</label>
answers.B: <label>B. That European colonizers concerned themselves deeply with turning profits</label>
answers.C: <label>C. That European colonizers were uniformly eager to force their cultural norms on native populations</label>
answers.D: <label>D. That European colonizers often resorted to armed force to impose their will on imperial subjects</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question requires use of evidence and an understanding of historical argumentation. Bentinck's reluctance to interfere with a longstanding Indian custom directly rebuts C, an accusation commonly launched by some historians against colonizing powers.

The authors of both passages served institutions associated with which of the following colonial techniques commonly used by Western imperial powers?

answers.A: <label>A. Direct rule by the crown</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Complete privatization of colonial authority</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Martial law enforced by sizable armies</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The chartering of companies to assume costs and share profits</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Both Bentinck and Simpson were administrators of companies that enjoyed government-chartered monopolies to economically exploit colonial territory. Techniques of colonial administration are a topic of key interest on the AP exam.

content: The innovation depicted in the image above is best regarded as

answers.A: <label>A. an advanced system of water management.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. an example of monumental architecture.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a method for fortifying cities.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. an agricultural technique associated with the Neolithic Revolution.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question relies on interpretive skill. Impressive as it may be, the qanat depicted here is clearly not a fortification or a piece of monumental architecture, making B and C incorrect. It is also too advanced to be associated with the Neolithic period, as in D.

content: Which of the following can most reasonably be concluded about the kind of society that would build the structure depicted in the image above?

answers.A: <label>A. It was located near a plentiful supply of water.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It lacked political centralization.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It was highly militaristic.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It possessed an impressive capacity to build infrastructure.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question also depends on interpretation and logical reasoning. Nothing about the qanat speaks to willingness or unwillingness to fight wars, and it is unlikely that a decentralized society could mobilize the labor to build such a structure, so B and C are not good choices. A ready supply of water would make the qanat less necessary, making A unlikely. Irrigation systems, especially this elaborate, would qualify as works of infrastructure.

content:
While some theorists in the Middle Ages argued that the jihad was a defensive warâ€¦ most authorities held that the obligation of jihad did not lapse until all the world was brought under the sway of Islam. The Bahr [al-Fava'id, or "Sea of Precious Virtues," written in the 1150s or 1160s] insists that the first duty of a Muslim ruler is to prosecute the jihad and bring about the victory of Islam, and if he does not do so and he makes peace with the infidel, that ruler would be better dead than alive, for he would be corrupting the world.
Robert Irwin, "Islam and the Crusades," 1995
It is strange how the Christians round Mount Lebanon, when they see any Muslim hermits, bring them food and treat them kindly, saying that these men are dedicated to the Great and Glorious God and that they should therefore share with them. Likewise, not one Christian merchant was stopped or hindered in Muslim territories.
Ibn Jubayr, Muslim scholar, traveling to Mecca and Jerusalem, ca. 1185

These two passages are best understood in the context of which of the following?

answers.A: <label>A. The influence of religion on interaction between cultures</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The use of religion to justify armed violence</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The syncretic fusion of different religious traditions</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The attempt of a religious group to proselytize to those following another faith</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question calls for contextualization and interpretation. The broad historical trend at work here is religious interchange between cultures. All the answers connect with that trend to one extent or another, but proselytization and syncretism, as in D and C, are not spoken of in the texts, and only the first text refers to linkages between religion and war, as in B. The widest possible take on the trend, expressed in A, is correct.

content:

The Bahr [al-Fava'id, or "Sea of Precious Virtues," written in the 1150s or 1160s] insists that the first duty of a Muslim ruler is to prosecute the jihad and bring about the victory of Islam, and if he does not do so and he makes peace with the infidel, that ruler would be better dead than alive, for he would be corrupting the world.
Robert Irwin, "Islam and the Crusades," 1995

Likewise, not one Christian merchant was stopped or hindered in Muslim territories.
Ibn Jubayr, Muslim scholar, traveling to Mecca and Jerusalem, ca. 1185

The first passage tends to support which of the following traditional historical assumptions?

answers.A: <label>A. That the majority of Muslims were more peaceful than Christians during the crusading era</label>
answers.B: <label>B. That most Muslims were interested only in protecting their own territory during the crusading era</label>
answers.C: <label>C. That many Muslims during the crusading era were driven by Islamic faith to be inherently violent</label>
answers.D: <label>D. That the ideology of holy war was taken seriously by Muslim elites during the crusading era</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question calls for contextualization, historical argumentation, and historical interpretation. Answers A and B are contradicted by the text, and C overstates the text's basic message. Answer D is the best encapsulation of the text's core thesis.

The second passage undermines traditional historical assumptions by

answers.A: <label>A. showing that state-level antagonisms in the Middle East during the crusading era were not always reflected in personal or economic life.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. showing how Middle Eastern Muslims during the crusading era did not take religious obligations as seriously as Christians did.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. showing how Muslims were on the whole kinder than Christians in the Middle East during the crusading era.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. showing how, in the Middle East during the crusading era, economic factors trumped all other considerations.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question also calls for contextualization, historical argumentation, and historical interpretation. The passage discussing conceptions of jihad is more relevant to rulers and political elites, whereas the second deals with the lived experience of people at the lower levels of society, where Crusade-related hostility would not have been as likely to be so heartfelt.

content: Which of the following can be most reasonably concluded from the information presented on the map above?

answers.A: <label>A. There was no single point of origin for the domestication of plants.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Barley was unsuitable for cultivation in zones near the equator.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Agriculture experienced an "out-of-Africa" diffusion similar to early human migration.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Rice was the first crop to be domesticated in Eurasia.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires use of evidence. Answers B and C are contradicted by clues provided by the map, and there is no evidence to support D.

content: The trends depicted in the map above began after which of the following environmental changes?

answers.A: <label>A. The Columbian Exchange</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The medieval climatic optimum</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The Little Ice Age</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The warming trends of the Neolithic</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question requires contextualization. Answers A, B, and C refer to events that took place long after the early domestication of plants.

content: The trends depicted in the map above led most directly to which of the following social developments?

answers.A: <label>A. Social stratification based on division of labor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Increased discrimination against ethnic minorities</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Heightened influence of organized religion</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Proto-industrialization of agricultural production</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question deals with causation and also requires knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not directly addressed by it. In this case, consequences are at stake. Answer B is far removed from the subject of the map. Answers C and D could conceivably be considered long-term or indirect aftereffects of the rise of sedentary societies based on agriculture, but the social stratification caused by the division of labor would have happened more immediately and more obviously.

content:
Every two months His Majesty sends from Lima 60,000 pesos to pay for the mita of the Indians. Up on the Huanacavelica range there are 3,000 or 4,000 Indians working in the mercury mine, with picks and hammers, breaking up the ore. And when they have filled up their little sacks, the poor fellows, loaded down, climb up those ladders and rigging, so distressing that a man can hardly get up them. That is the way they work in this mine, with many lights and the loud noise of the pounding and great confusion. Nor is that the greatest evil; that is due to thievish and undisciplined superintendents. According to His Majesty's warrant, the mine owners at Potosí have a right to the mita of 13,300 Indians. These mita Indians earn each day 4 reals. Besides these there are others not under obligation, who hire themselves out voluntarily: these each get from 12 to 16 reals, and some up to 24, according to how well they wield their picks or their reputation for knowing how to get the ore out.
Antonio Vasquez de Espinosa, report on mining in Huanacavelica and Potosí, 1620s
The third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined is that from the time they first came under Russian control, they have been forced to pay yasak tribute. Some have paid in sables, others in red foxes, still others in cash. At first there were plenty of furbearing animals there, but now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands, from the shores of the Arctic Ocean all the way south to the great Lena River. Moreover, almost half the natives cannot hunt because they no longer have horses, many of which have been pawned to the yasak collectors.
Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744

Both passages are best seen in the context of which of the following broad developments?

answers.A: <label>A. Emerging systems of coerced labor</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The expansion of chattel slavery</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Increased reliance on prison-camp workforces</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Colonization of overseas territories by joint-stock companies</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question calls for contextualization and knowledge of broad trends emphasized by the AP exam. Neither case describes workers who are actually owned by other people, and prison-camp labor is not referred to, so B and C are incorrect. Both texts involve colonization, but Siberia was not an overseas territory for Russia, and joint-stock companies were not involved with Spanish colonization of the Americas.

content:

That is the way they work in this mine, with many lights and the loud noise of the pounding and great confusion. Nor is that the greatest evil; that is due to thievish and undisciplined superintendents. According to His Majesty's warrant, the mine owners at Potosí have a right to the mita of 13,300 Indians. These mita Indians earn each day 4 reals. Besides these there are others not under obligation, who hire themselves out voluntarily: these each get from 12 to 16 reals, and some up to 24, according to how well they wield their picks or their reputation for knowing how to get the ore out.
Antonio Vasquez de Espinosa, report on mining in Huanacavelica and Potosí, 1620s
The third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined is that from the time they first came under Russian control, they have been forced to pay yasak tribute. Some have paid in sables, others in red foxes, still others in cash. At first there were plenty of furbearing animals there, but now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands, from the shores of the Arctic Ocean all the way south to the great Lena River. Moreover, almost half the natives cannot hunt because they no longer have horses, many of which have been pawned to the yasak collectors.
Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744

The system of labor described in the first passage came into being in which of the following ways?

answers.A: <label>A. Spanish colonists enslaved native American populations outright.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Spain refused to purchase slaves from Africa, relying instead on native American labor.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Spanish authorities adapted local forms of labor mobilization for their own purposes.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Spanish landowners came to depend heavily on plantation monoculture.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This document refers to the mit'a system of corvée labor that had been used by several Andean societies, including the Incan Empire, prior to the arrival of the Europeans. After attempting to enslave native Americans by means of the encomienda system, Spanish colonizers mobilized labor both by relying on slaves from Africa and forcing native Americans to work according to the dictates of the preexisting mit'a system. This was not technically slavery, but counts as a form of coerced labor.

Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744

According to the second passage, which of the following contributed most to the burden faced by native Siberians attempting to fulfill their tribute obligations?

answers.A: <label>A. Interference by Russian Orthodox missionaries</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Native inexperience in hunting deep into the subarctic tundra</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Competition from Russian hunters and trappers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Overhunting and depletion of furbearing animals</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) This question calls for interpretation and careful reading. Answer B makes little sense, given how well native populations generally adapted to their home territories. Answers A and C refer to troubles that frequently plagued native Siberians, but the passage refers specifically to the growing shortable of the furbearing animals whose pelts formed the tribute payments that natives owed their Russian colonizers.

content:
Every two months His Majesty sends from Lima 60,000 pesos to pay for the mita of the Indians. Up on the Huanacavelica range there are 3,000 or 4,000 Indians working in the mercury mine, with picks and hammers, breaking up the ore. And when they have filled up their little sacks, the poor fellows, loaded down, climb up those ladders and rigging, so distressing that a man can hardly get up them. That is the way they work in this mine, with many lights and the loud noise of the pounding and great confusion. Nor is that the greatest evil; that is due to thievish and undisciplined superintendents. According to His Majesty's warrant, the mine owners at Potosí have a right to the mita of 13,300 Indians. These mita Indians earn each day 4 reals. Besides these there are others not under obligation, who hire themselves out voluntarily: these each get from 12 to 16 reals, and some up to 24, according to how well they wield their picks or their reputation for knowing how to get the ore out.
Antonio Vasquez de Espinosa, report on mining in Huanacavelica and Potosí, 1620s
The third principal reason the local Yakut and Tungus natives are ruined is that from the time they first came under Russian control, they have been forced to pay yasak tribute. Some have paid in sables, others in red foxes, still others in cash. At first there were plenty of furbearing animals there, but now there are no sables and not many foxes in those lands, from the shores of the Arctic Ocean all the way south to the great Lena River. Moreover, almost half the natives cannot hunt because they no longer have horses, many of which have been pawned to the yasak collectors.
Heinrich von Füch, "On the Treatment of Natives in Northeast Siberia," 1744

Which of the following factors, not mentioned in the second passage, would have been most likely to create added difficulties for native Siberians attempting to fulfill their tribute obligations?

answers.A: <label>A. The arrival of rival hunters from China and Japan</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The impact of epidemic diseases brought by Russian settlers</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The general warming of the climate during this time period</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The reduced demand for furs among European and Asian elites</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question requires contextualization and knowledge of broad trends associated with the stimulus material but not necessarily mentioned by it. Quite commonly, native populations suffered terribly from epidemic diseases brought to their communities by colonizers from far away. Native Siberians who encountered Russian settlers and trappers were no exception.

Flow of major goods and commodities, Indian Ocean trade network, ca. 600 to 1450

Which of the statements below is most solidly supported by the information contained in the web above?

answers.A: <label>A. China produced the highest volume of trade goods in this system of exchange.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. India served as the geographical hub of this system of exchange.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. East Africa experienced an accelerated rate of urbanization as a result of this system of exchange.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Middle East produced the highest-quality goods in this system of exchange.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question calls for interpretation. The chart provides a sense of the directional flow of goods, but no data beyond that. Answer A cannot be supported by the information given, and the same is true of D, which is also subjective. Answer C is actually true, but likewise cannot be supported by the chart.

content:
Flow of major goods and commodities, Indian Ocean trade network, ca. 600 to 1450

Which of the following technological innovations played the largest role in enabling this system of exchange?

answers.A: <label>A. The outrigger canoe</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Lateen sails</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The lodestone compass</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Stern rudders</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question calls for knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not referred to it directly. Answer A applies more to the Pacific, and while C and D were important, the development of lateen sails, which used wind more efficiently than older sailing systems, was key to the open-water navigation necessary for the creation of the Indian Ocean trade network.

Flow of major goods and commodities, Indian Ocean trade network, ca. 600 to 1450

This system of exchange would have encouraged which of the following social and cultural developments most directly?

answers.A: <label>A. The diffusion of Buddhism throughout Asia</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The weakening of traditional social hierarchies</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The formation of merchant diaspora communities</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The rise of Islamic patriarchalism in East Africa</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question also calls for knowledge related to the stimulus material, and tests causation as well. Answer A applies more to the Silk Road, and B and D are even less relevant to the chart. The Indian Ocean trade network is famous for having created far-flung merchant communities from East Africa to China.

The economic relationships associated with this system of exchange was most disrupted by which of the following?

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) Likewise, this question tests causation and contextualization, and requires knowledge related to the stimulus material. The development described in B actually took place, but after the cause of the true disruption, which is given in D. Answers A and C are decoys.

Relief statue of Sassanid Persian king Shapur II, ca. 350 C.E.

The image is most likely associated with

answers.A: <label>A. a work of monumental architecture.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a state-sponsored public works project.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

(A) This question calls for contextualization and interpretation. While none of the answers is impossible, the key AP topic most likely at stake here is monumental architecture. The clear intent to impress the onlooker is the best clue for this conclusion.

content:
Relief statue of Sassanid Persian king Shapur II, ca. 350 C.E.

It is most likely meant to depict which of the following scenes?

answers.A: <label>A. A subject in awe of the divine power of his king</label>
answers.B: <label>B. A slave attending upon his noble master</label>
answers.C: <label>C. An enemy acknowledging defeat before a mighty conqueror</label>
answers.D: <label>D. A performer taking a bow before a royal patron</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question calls for use of evidence and historical interpretation. This carving, of the Persian emperor Shapur II, is clearly intended to convey a sense of majesty and military prowess. Answers A and B are not implausible, but C seems most likely, given the humble posture of the kneeling figure.

content:
That day the Reverend Xuanzang was chosen from among all the monks. He had been a monk from infancy, and ever since birth he had eaten vegetarian food and observed the prohibitions. His maternal grandfather was an imperial commander, Yin Kaishan. His father Chen Guangrui had come top in the Palace Examination and had been appointed a grand secretary in the Imperial Library. Xuanzang, however, had no interest in honour and glory, and his only joy was to cultivate Nirvana. His virtue was great; of the thousand sutras and ten thousand holy books there was not a single one that he did not know.
â€¦
He looked to the West and prayed, "I am the believer Chen Xuanzang sent on imperial orders to fetch the scriptures. If I am fated to have a disciple, may I be able to unseal the golden words and release the divine Monkey King to come with me to the Vulture Peak. If I am not fated to have a disciple, and this monkey is an evil monster who has deceived me and will do me no good, then may I be unable to remove the seal." When he had prayed he bowed again.
From Wu Chengen, Journey to the West, ca. 1590s

In which of the following ways does the excerpt above most complicate historians' understanding of the career of the Chinese monk and traveler Xuanzang?

answers.A: <label>A. It highly fictionalizes the story of Xuanzang's accomplishments.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It was written long after the time period in which Xuanzang lived.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It casts doubt on the actual existence of Xuanzang.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It is widely considered by scholars to be a forgery.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question tests historiographical thinking, and also interpretation. Answer B refers to something true about the text, but while having been written after the fact can affect the value of a source, fictionalization complicates it far more. If this were the only available source regarding Xuanzang, C would be more applicable; there is nothing to indicate that D is true.

content:

Xuanzang, however, had no interest in honour and glory, and his only joy was to cultivate Nirvana. From Wu Chengen, Journey to the West, ca. 1590s

The journeys undertaken by Xuanzang in the 600s C.E. are most fruitfully understood

answers.A: <label>A. in the context of widespread missionary efforts during the time period in question.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. as an example of the role played by interregional travelers in promoting understanding between cultures.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. in light of the interconnections between religious syncretism and interregional trade.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. as an instance of deep-seated hostility between Buddhists living in different parts of Asia.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question tests contextualization, and interpretation, and knowledge related to the stimulus material, but not spoken of it explicitly in the text. Answer D is completely unsupported by the text or by knowledge of the actual Xuanzang's career. While missionaries were important in spreading Buddhism, as in A, this was not Xuanzang's mission, and syncretism, spoken of in C, is not at issue here.

Accounts of Xuanzang's travels from both the 600s and 1500s C.E. are inspired by which of the following accomplishments?

answers.A: <label>A. Xuanzang's career as a spy against the Gupta Empire</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Xuanzang's conversion of South Asian Hindus</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Xuanzang's study and retrieval of Buddhist texts from India</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Xuanzang's opening of new trade routes to Southeast Asia</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question also requires knowledge related to the topic covered by the stimulus material, but not mentioned directly. Only C accurately describes what the real-life Xuanzang accomplished.

content: The map above depicts which of the following historical processes?

answers.A: <label>A. The consolidation of a continent-wide state</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The formation of an alliance system against a common enemy</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The disintegration of an empire into smaller entities</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The emergence of religious divisions within a large nation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question requires interpretation and contextualization. The map depicts the separation of a once-united Mongol Empire into smaller states.

content: The economic impact of the process depicted by the map would have been felt most strongly

answers.A: <label>A. in the Indian Ocean.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. along the Silk Road.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. in the Mediterranean Sea.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. in the Pacific Ocean.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

(B) This question tests causation and requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not directly alluded to by it. While all the locations listed were connected by trade, the network which overlapped the most with Mongol territory—and was most affected by political trends in the Mongol Empire—was the overland Silk Road.

content: Which of the following religions became more firmly established as a result of the process depicted by the map?

answers.A: <label>A. Confucianism and Islam</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Buddhism and Christianity</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Islam and Buddhism</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Christianity and Islam</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) This question likewise tests causation and requires knowledge related to the stimulus material but not explicitly mentioned by it. While Mongol conquerers were highly adaptable when it came to religion (and adopted all the faiths listed in the possible answers), the two faiths that they turned to in the largest numbers were Buddhism (both in Central Asia and East Asia) and Islam (mainly in Central Asia).

content:
Woman, wake up; the bell of reason is being heard throughout the whole universe; discover your rights. Enslaved man has multiplied his strength, [but] having become free, he has become unjust to his companion. Oh, women, women! When will you cease to be blind? What advantage have you received from the Revolution? A more pronounced scorn, a more marked disdain. If our leaders persist, courageously oppose the force of reason to their empty pretentions of superiority. Regardless of what barriers confront you, it is in your power to free yourselves!
Olympe de Gouges, "Declaration of the Rights of Woman and the Female Citizen," 1791
The independence? Nothing of what I hoped for was achieved. I had expected that my children would be able to have an education, but they did not get it. We were poor peasants then, we are poor peasants now. Nothing has changed. Everything is the same. The only thing is that we are free, the war is over, we work without fear—but apart from that, nothing has changed.
Halima Ghomri, interviewed in the 1970s, after Algeria's war of independence

Which of the following observations about revolutions and gender is best supported by the first passage?

answers.A: <label>A. Revolutionary progressivism does not always concern itself with gender equality.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Women typically assume leadership roles during times of revolution.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Women rarely support revolutions and therefore receive little benefit from them.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Revolutionary movements are generally uninterested in women's rights.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) This question requires close reading and interpretation. While in both texts, women are expressing dissatisfaction with the outcomes of revolutions they have taken part in, their complaints do not support A or D, and certainly not C. Answer A best captures the general trend—the tendency of many revolutions to neglect women's concerns—without overstating the case.
